ğŸ§± Cells vÃ  Disks

1. n-Disks vÃ  n-Spheres

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (n-Disk):

\[D^n = \{x \in \mathbb{R}^n : ||x|| \leq 1\}\]

Closed unit ball.

Examples:

  • Dâ° = {point}
  • DÂ¹ = [-1, 1] (interval)
  • DÂ² = closed unit disk
  • DÂ³ = closed unit ball

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (n-Sphere):

\[S^{n-1} = \partial D^n = \{x \in \mathbb{R}^n : ||x|| = 1\}\]

Boundary cá»§a Dâ¿.

Examples:

  • Sâ»Â¹ = âˆ… (boundary cá»§a point)
  • Sâ° = {-1, 1} (two points)
  • SÂ¹ = circle
  • SÂ² = sphere

Interior (Open Cell):

\[\text{int}(D^n) = D^n \setminus S^{n-1} = \{x : ||x|| < 1\}\]

Homeomorphic vá»›i â„â¿.

2. Attaching Cells

Idea: Build space by gluing cells.

Attaching n-cell:
Start vá»›i space X^(n-1).
Glue n-disk Dâ¿ via attaching map Ï†: Sâ¿â»Â¹ â†’ X^(n-1).

Construction:

\[X^n = X^{n-1} \sqcup D^n / \sim\]

where x ~ Ï†(x) âˆ€x âˆˆ Sâ¿â»Â¹.

Quotient topology.

Notation: X^n = X^(n-1) âˆª_Ï† Dâ¿ (cell attached).

Example: Building SÂ²

  • Start: Xâ»Â¹ = âˆ…
  • Add 0-cell (point): Xâ° = {*}
  • Add 2-cell: XÂ² = {*} âˆª_Ï† DÂ² = SÂ²

Attaching map: Ï†: SÂ¹ â†’ {*} constant.
Result: DÂ² vá»›i boundary collapsed = SÂ². âœ“

ğŸ—ï¸ CW Complex Definition

1. Inductive Definition

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (CW Complex):
CW complex X lÃ  space constructed:

Step 0: Start vá»›i discrete set Xâ° (0-skeleton) = collection cá»§a points (0-cells).

Step n: Assuming X^(n-1) constructed (n-1 skeleton).
Attach collection {D^n_Î±}_Î± via attaching maps Ï†_Î±: S^(n-1) â†’ X^(n-1):

\[X^n = X^{n-1} \sqcup_\alpha D^n_\alpha / \sim\]

Quotient topology.

Final space:

\[X = \bigcup_{n=0}^\infty X^n\]

vá»›i weak topology: A âŠ† X closed âŸº A âˆ© X^n closed âˆ€n.

Terminology:

  • n-cell e^n_Î± = interior cá»§a D^n_Î± (open cell)
  • n-skeleton X^n = union cá»§a all cells dimension â‰¤ n
  • Finite CW complex: Finitely many cells
  • Finite-dimensional: X^n = X cho some n

2. Axioms (Alternative Definition)

CW complex = X vá»›i collection {e^n_Î±} (â€œcellsâ€) satisfying:

(CW1) X = â‹ƒ e^n_Î± (disjoint union cá»§a cells)

(CW2) âˆ€Î±: âˆƒ characteristic map Î¦_Î±: D^n â†’ X continuous, Î¦_Î± homeomorphism onto e^n_Î± âˆª (lower dim cells)

(CW3) Closure-finite: cl(e^n_Î±) intersects finitely many cells

(CW4) Weak topology: A closed âŸº A âˆ© cl(e^n_Î±) closed âˆ€Î±

Remark: Definition flexibleâ€”many ways to say same thing.

ğŸŒŸ Examples

1. Spheres Sâ¿

CW structure:

  • Xâ° = {*} (one 0-cell)
  • X^n = Xâ° âˆª_Ï† D^n (one n-cell attached)

Attaching map: Ï†: S^(n-1) â†’ {*} constant.

Result: D^n vá»›i boundary collapsed = S^n. âœ“

Cell count: Two cells total (one 0-cell, one n-cell).

2. Torus TÂ²

CW structure (minimal):

  • Xâ° = {*} (one 0-cell)
  • XÂ¹ = SÂ¹ âˆ¨ SÂ¹ (two 1-cells attachedâ€”figure eight)
  • XÂ² = TÂ² (one 2-cell attached)

Attaching map 2-cell: Ï†: SÂ¹ â†’ SÂ¹ âˆ¨ SÂ¹, going around loops a b aâ»Â¹ bâ»Â¹.

Cell count: 1 + 2 + 1 = 4 cells.

Alternative: Square vá»›i edges identified (fundamental polygon).

3. Projective Space â„P^n

CW structure:

  • One cell in each dimension: eâ°, eÂ¹, eÂ², â€¦, e^n

Construction:
â„P^n = â„P^(n-1) âˆª_Ï† D^n.

Attaching map: Ï†: S^(n-1) â†’ â„P^(n-1) quotient map (antipodal).

Cell count: n + 1 cells.

Example â„PÂ²:

  • eâ° (point)
  • eÂ¹ (attached â†’ â„PÂ¹ â‰… SÂ¹)
  • eÂ² (attached via antipodal â†’ â„PÂ²)

4. Graph (1-Complex)

Any graph = CW complex:

  • Vertices = 0-cells
  • Edges = 1-cells (attach 1-disks = intervals)

Example: Circle graph SÂ¹ = one 0-cell, one 1-cell (loop).

5. Simplicial Complexes âŠ† CW Complexes

Simplicial complex: Glue simplices (triangles, tetrahedra).
Special case cá»§a CW complex (stricter requirements).

CW more general: Arbitrary attaching maps, not just vertex-to-vertex.

ğŸ” Properties

1. Hausdorff?

Warning: CW complex not always Hausdorff!

Counterexample:
â€œLine vá»›i two originsâ€â€”CW but not Hausdorff.

Theorem (Sufficient Condition):
Finite CW complex Hausdorff.

General case: Locally finite CW complex Hausdorff.

Remark: Most â€œreasonableâ€ CW complexes Hausdorff.

2. Compactness

Theorem:
Finite CW complex compact.

Proof: Finite union cá»§a compact cells (closed disks). âœ“

Infinite CW complex: Usually not compact (e.g., â„â¿ vá»›i standard cell structure).

3. Homotopy Type

Key Property:
CW complexes have nice homotopy properties.

Theorem (Whitehead):
f: X â†’ Y CW complexes, f induces isomorphism on all homotopy groups â‡’ f homotopy equivalence.

Consequence: Homotopy type determined by homotopy groups.

Theorem (CW Approximation):
Má»i space (reasonable conditions) homotopy equivalent vá»›i CW complex.

Moral: For homotopy theory, suffices study CW complexes!

ğŸ“ Cellular Homology

1. Chain Complex

Idea: Compute homology directly tá»« cell structure.

Cellular chain complex:

\[\cdots \to C_n \xrightarrow{\partial_n} C_{n-1} \to \cdots \to C_1 \xrightarrow{\partial_1} C_0 \to 0\]

C_n = â„¤^{(# n-cells)} (free abelian group generated by n-cells).

Boundary map âˆ‚_n: Encodes how n-cells attach to (n-1)-skeleton.

2. Cellular Boundary Formula

Formula:
âˆ‚(e^n_Î±) = Î£_Î² d_Î±Î² e^(n-1)_Î²

where d_Î±Î² = degree cá»§a attaching map restricted to Î²-cell.

Computation: Use algebraic topology techniques.

3. Cellular Homology Groups

Definition:

\[H_n^{CW}(X) = \ker(\partial_n) / \text{im}(\partial_{n+1})\]

Theorem (Equivalence):

\[H_n^{CW}(X) \cong H_n(X)\]

(Cellular homology = singular homology.)

Advantage: Cellular homology often easier compute (finite-dimensional chains for finite CW).

4. Examples

Example 1: S^n

Cell structure: eâ°, e^n.
C_k = â„¤ if k = 0 or n, else 0.
Boundary maps = 0 (no cells to attach between).

Result:

\[H_k(S^n) = \begin{cases} \mathbb{Z} & k = 0, n \\ 0 & \text{else} \end{cases}\]

âœ“

Example 2: TÂ² (Torus)

Cell structure: 1 vertex (eâ°), 2 edges (eÂ¹_a, eÂ¹_b), 1 face (eÂ²).

Chain complex:
â„¤ â† â„¤Â² â† â„¤

Boundary: âˆ‚(eÂ²) = [a,b] commutator = 0 in homology.
âˆ‚(eÂ¹) = 0 (loops).

Result:

\[H_0(T^2) = \mathbb{Z}, \quad H_1(T^2) = \mathbb{Z}^2, \quad H_2(T^2) = \mathbb{Z}\]

âœ“ (Matches known homology!)

Example 3: â„PÂ²

Cell structure: eâ°, eÂ¹, eÂ².
âˆ‚(eÂ²) = 2 eÂ¹ (attaching via double cover).
âˆ‚(eÂ¹) = 0.

Result:

\[H_0(\mathbb{RP}^2) = \mathbb{Z}, \quad H_1(\mathbb{RP}^2) = \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}, \quad H_2(\mathbb{RP}^2) = 0\]

âœ“ (Non-orientable â‡’ Hâ‚‚ = 0!)

ğŸ§  Fundamental Papers & References

Classic Works

    Introduced CW complexes

  2. Whitehead - â€œCombinatorial Homotopy IIâ€ (1949)
    Whitehead theorem

Textbooks

    Comprehensive treatment

  2. Edwin Spanier - Algebraic Topology, Chapter 7
    Detailed theory

ğŸ”— Applications and Connections

Algebraic Topology - Homology

Cellular Homology: Efficient computation for CW complexes.

Homotopy Theory

CW Approximation: Every space ~ CW complex (for homotopy).

K-Theory

Vector Bundles: Classified using CW structure.

Differential Topology

Manifolds: Admit CW structures (handle decompositions).

Topology of Data

TDA (Topological Data Analysis): Simplicial complexes (special CW) model data.

ğŸ§© Exercises

Cells

  1. Verify:
    D^n homeomorphic vá»›i closed unit ball. S^(n-1) = âˆ‚D^n.

  2. Open Cell:
    int(D^n) homeomorphic vá»›i â„â¿. Explicit homeomorphism?

  3. Attaching:
    X = {}, attach DÂ² via Ï†: SÂ¹ â†’ {} constant. Verify result = SÂ².

CW Structures

  1. SÂ¹:
    Describe CW structure vá»›i 1 vertex, 1 edge (loop).

  2. SÂ²:
    Describe CW structure vá»›i minimal cells (1 vertex, 1 face).

  3. TÂ²:
    Write detailed CW structure: vertices, edges, face. Verify homeomorphic vá»›i torus.

Examples

  1. â„PÂ¹:
    â„PÂ¹ CW structure: eâ°, eÂ¹. Attaching map?

  2. â„PÂ²:
    CW structure: eâ°, eÂ¹, eÂ². Describe attachments.

  3. Graph:
    Draw graph, identify 0-cells (vertices) vÃ  1-cells (edges).

Homology

  1. S^n Homology:
    Use cellular structure compute H_k(S^n).

  2. TÂ² Homology:
    Chain complex: â„¤ â† â„¤Â² â† â„¤. Compute ker/im, verify H_1(TÂ²) = â„¤Â².

  3. â„PÂ² Homology:
    âˆ‚(eÂ²) = 2eÂ¹. Compute H_1(â„PÂ²) = â„¤/2â„¤.

Properties

  1. Hausdorff:
    Finite CW complex Hausdorff. Sketch proof.

  2. Compact:
    Finite CW complex compact. Why?

  3. Homotopy Type:
    SÂ² vÃ  DÂ² homotopy equivalent? CW structures?

Advanced

  1. Whitehead Theorem:
    f: X â†’ Y CW, isomorphism Ï€_n âˆ€n â‡’ homotopy equivalence. Research statement.

  2. CW Approximation:
    Every manifold homotopy equivalent vá»›i CW complex. Example: SÂ² â‰ƒ CW(SÂ²).

  3. Handle Decomposition:
    Manifolds admit handle decompositions (special CW). Example: TÂ² tá»« handles.
